017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt;
018
019import com.badlogic.gdx.math.Interpolation;
020import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
021import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.FloatArray;
022import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
023
024/**
025 * Static methods for handling gradients of smoothly-changing colors, typically inside of {@link FloatArray}s.
026 * The intent is for the FloatArray to be used as a sequence of packed float IPT colors. You can create a new
027 * FloatArray gradient with {@link #makeGradient(float, float, int, Interpolation)}, but any FloatArray will work
028 * (although it only makes sense if it contains packed float colors or is empty). Once you have a FloatArray, you can
029 * pass it to {@link #appendGradient(FloatArray, float, float, int, Interpolation)} to make a gradient between two
030 * colors, or {@link #appendGradientChain(FloatArray, int, Interpolation, float...)} to make a gradient between more
031 * than two colors. You can also customize each section between colors with
032 * {@link #appendPartialGradient(FloatArray, float, float, int, Interpolation)}, which is just like appendGradient() but
033 * doesn't add the end color (since it is the start color of the next partial gradient, until you finally end by
034 * appending just the end). Using appendPartialGradient(), you can have each transition use a different number of steps.
035 */
036public class GradientTools {
037    /**
038     * No need to instantiate.
039     */
040    private GradientTools(){
041    }
042
043    /**
044     * Creates a FloatArray gradient from the packed float IPT color {@code start} to the packed float IPT color
045     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using linear interpolation.
046     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
047     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end on
048     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
049     * @return a new FloatArray that contains the requested gradient
050     */
051    public static FloatArray makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps) {
052        return makeGradient(start, end, steps, Interpolation.linear);
053    }
054    /**
055     * Creates a FloatArray gradient from the packed float IPT color {@code start} to the packed float IPT color
056     * {@code end}, taking the specified number of steps and using the specified Interpolation for how it transitions.
057     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
058     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end on
059     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2, and must be non-negative
060     * @param interpolation a libGDX Interpolation that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
061     * @return a new FloatArray that contains the requested gradient
062     */
063    public static FloatArray makeGradient(float start, float end, int steps, Interpolation interpolation) {
064        FloatArray appending = new FloatArray(steps);
065        if(steps <= 0) {
066            return appending;
067        }
068        if(steps == 1) {
069            appending.add(start);
070            return appending;
071        }
072        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
073        return appending;
074    }
075
076    /**
077     * Appends a gradient from the packed float IPT color {@code start} to the packed float IPT color {@code end},
078     * taking the specified number of steps and using linear Interpolation for how it transitions.
079     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
080     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
081     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end on
082     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
083     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
084     */
085    public static FloatArray appendGradient(FloatArray appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
086        return appendGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolation.linear);
087    }
088    /**
089     * Appends a gradient from the packed float IPT color {@code start} to the packed float IPT color {@code end},
090     * taking the specified number of steps and using the specified Interpolation for how it transitions.
091     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
092     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
093     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end on
094     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
095     * @param interpolation a libGDX Interpolation that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
096     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
097     */
098    public static FloatArray appendGradient(FloatArray appending, float start, float end, int steps, Interpolation interpolation) {
099        if(appending == null)
100            return null;
101        if(steps <= 0) {
102            return appending;
103        }
104        if(steps == 1) {
105            appending.add(start);
106            return appending;
107        }
108        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
109        appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps - 1, interpolation).add(end);
110        return appending;
111    }
112
113    /**
114     * Appends a gradient between several packed float IPT colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
115     * Interpolation for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
116     * {@code steps} colors.
117     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
118     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
119     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float IPT colors that this will interpolate through in order
120     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
121     */
122    public static FloatArray appendGradientChain(FloatArray appending, int steps, float... chain) {
123        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolation.linear, chain);
124    }
125
126    /**
127     * Appends a gradient between several packed float IPT colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses linear
128     * Interpolation for the whole gradient. Appends to the end of {@code appending} and produces a total of
129     * {@code steps} colors.
130     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
131     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
132     * @param chain a FloatArray of packed float IPT colors that this will interpolate through in order
133     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
134     */
135    public static FloatArray appendGradientChain(FloatArray appending, int steps, FloatArray chain) {
136        return appendGradientChain(appending, steps, Interpolation.linear, chain);
137    }
138
139    /**
140     * Appends a gradient between several packed float IPT colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
141     * Interpolation for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
142     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
143     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
144     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
145     * @param interpolation a libGDX Interpolation that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
146     * @param chain a FloatArray of packed float IPT colors that this will interpolate through in order
147     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
148     */
149    public static FloatArray appendGradientChain(FloatArray appending, int steps, Interpolation interpolation, FloatArray chain) {
150        if (appending == null)
151            return null;
152        if(chain == null)
153            return appending;
154        if (steps <= 0 || chain.size == 0) {
155            return appending;
156        }
157        if (steps == 1 || chain.size == 1) {
158            appending.add(chain.first());
159            return appending;
160        }
161        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
162        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.size - 1;
163        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
164        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
165            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
166            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
167            int idx = (int)splint;
168            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(chain.get(idx), chain.get(idx+1), MathUtils.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
169            change += step;
170        }
171        appending.add(chain.get(splits));
172        return appending;
173    }
174
175    /**
176     * Appends a gradient between several packed float IPT colors provided in {@code chain}. This uses the specified
177     * Interpolation for the whole gradient, which can make some colors use smaller sections than others. Appends to the
178     * end of {@code appending} and produces a total of {@code steps} colors.
179     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
180     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
181     * @param interpolation a libGDX Interpolation that can be used to customize how start transitions to end
182     * @param chain an array or varargs of packed float IPT colors that this will interpolate through in order
183     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to the end
184     */
185    public static FloatArray appendGradientChain(FloatArray appending, int steps, Interpolation interpolation, float... chain) {
186        if (appending == null)
187            return null;
188        if(chain == null)
189            return appending;
190        if (steps <= 0 || chain.length == 0) {
191            return appending;
192        }
193        if (steps == 1 || chain.length == 1) {
194            appending.add(chain[0]);
195            return appending;
196        }
197        appending.ensureCapacity(steps);
198        int limit = steps - 1, splits = chain.length - 1;
199        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
200        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
201            float interp = interpolation.apply(change);
202            float splint = Math.min(Math.max(interp * splits, 0f), splits - 0.000001f);
203            int idx = (int)splint;
204            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(chain[idx], chain[idx+1], MathUtils.norm(idx, idx +1, splint)));
205            change += step;
206        }
207        appending.add(chain[splits]);
208        return appending;
209    }
210
211    /**
212     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatArray, float, float, int)}, but does not include
213     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
214     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
215     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
216     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
217     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
218     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end just before
219     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
220     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
221     */
222    public static FloatArray appendPartialGradient(FloatArray appending, float start, float end, int steps) {
223        return appendPartialGradient(appending, start, end, steps, Interpolation.linear);
224    }
225    /**
226     * Exactly like {@link #appendGradient(FloatArray, float, float, int, Interpolation)}, but does not include
227     * {@code end} in what it appends to {@code appending}. This is intended for the implementation of chained
228     * gradients, where the end of a previous gradient becomes the start of the next one. This still uses the specified
229     * number of steps, it just doesn't append {@code end} in the last step.
230     * @param appending a FloatArray that will be appended to
231     * @param start the packed float IPT color to start with
232     * @param end the packed float IPT color to end just before
233     * @param steps how many steps the gradient should use; usually greater than 2
234     * @param interpolation a libGDX Interpolation that can be used to customize how start transitions toward end
235     * @return {@code appending}, after adding the gradient to its end
236     */
237    public static FloatArray appendPartialGradient(FloatArray appending, float start, float end, int steps, Interpolation interpolation){
238        if(appending == null)
239            return null;
240        if(steps <= 0) {
241            return appending;
242        }
243        if(steps == 1) {
244            appending.add(start);
245            return appending;
246        }
247        int limit = steps;
248        float step = 1f / steps, change = 0f;
249        for (int i = 0; i < limit; i++) {
250            appending.add(FloatColors.lerpFloatColors(start, end, interpolation.apply(change)));
251            change += step;
252        }
253        return appending;
254    }
255}
